member.name: P:Raven.Abstractions.Data.IndexQuery.CutoffEtag
member.summary: Gets or sets the cutoff etag
member.remarks: Cutoff etag is used to check if the index has already process a document with the given etag. Unlike Cutoff, which uses dates and is susceptible to clock syncronization issues between machines, cutoff etag doesn't rely on both the server and client having a syncronized clock and can work without it. However, when used to query map/reduce indexes, it does NOT guarantee that the document that this etag belong to is actually considered for the results. What it does it guarantee that the document has been mapped, but not that the mapped values has been reduce. Since map/reduce queries, by their nature,tend to be far less susceptible to issues with staleness, this is considered to be an acceptable tradeoff. If you need absolute no staleness with a map/reduce index, you will need to ensure syncronized clocks and use the Cutoff date option, instead.

member.name: T:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldIndexing
member.summary: Options for indexing a field

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldIndexing.No
member.summary: Do not index the field value. This field can thus not be searched, but one can still access its contents provided it is stored.

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldIndexing.Analyzed
member.summary: Index the tokens produced by running the field's value through an Analyzer. This is useful for common text.

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldIndexing.NotAnalyzed
member.summary: Index the field's value without using an Analyzer, so it can be searched. As no analyzer is used the value will be stored as a single term. This is useful for unique Ids like product numbers.

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldIndexing.Default
member.summary: Index this field using the default internal analyzer: LowerCaseKeywordAnalyzer

member.name: T:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldStorage
member.summary: Specifies whether and how a field should be stored.

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldStorage.Yes
member.summary: Store the original field value in the index. This is useful for short texts like a document's title which should be displayed with the results. The value is stored in its original form, i.e. no analyzer is used before it is stored.

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldStorage.No
member.summary: Do not store the field value in the index.

member.name: F:Raven.Abstractions.Indexing.FieldStorage.Compress
member.summary: Store the original field value in the index in a compressed form. This is useful for long documents and for binary valued fields.

member.name: T:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools
member.summary:
Provides support for converting dates to strings and vice-versa. The strings are structured so that lexicographic sorting orders them by date, which makes them suitable for use as field values and search terms.
This class also helps you to limit the resolution of your dates. Do not save dates with a finer resolution than you really need, as then RangeQuery and PrefixQuery will require more memory and become slower.
Compared to {@link DateField} the strings generated by the methods in this class take slightly more space, unless your selected resolution is set to Resolution.DAY or lower.
Another approach is {@link NumericUtils}, which provides a sortable binary representation (prefix encoded) of numeric values, which date/time are. For indexing a {@link Date} or {@link Calendar}, just get the Unix timestamp as long using {@link Date#getTime} or {@link Calendar#getTimeInMillis} and index this as a numeric value with {@link NumericField} and use {@link NumericRangeQuery} to query it.

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.DateToString(System.DateTime,Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.Resolution)
member.summary: Converts a Date to a string suitable for indexing.
member.returns: a string in format yyyyMMddHHmmssSSS or shorter, depending on resolution; using GMT as timezone

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.TimeToString(System.Int64,Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.Resolution)
member.summary: Converts a millisecond time to a string suitable for indexing.
member.param: the date expressed as milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT
member.returns: a string in format yyyyMMddHHmmssSSS or shorter, depending on resolution; using GMT as timezone

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.StringToTime(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string produced by timeToString or DateToString back to a time, represented as the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT.
member.param: the date string to be converted
member.returns: the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT
member.throws: ParseException if dateString is not in the
member.summary: expected format

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.StringToDate(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string produced by timeToString or DateToString back to a time, represented as a Date object.
member.param: the date string to be converted
member.returns: the parsed time as a Date object
member.throws: ParseException if dateString is not in the
member.summary: expected format

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.Round(System.DateTime,Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.Resolution)
member.summary: Limit a date's resolution. For example, the date 2004-09-21 13:50:11 will be changed to 2004-09-01 00:00:00 when using Resolution.MONTH.
member.param: The desired resolution of the date to be returned
member.returns: the date with all values more precise than resolution set to 0 or 1

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.Round(System.Int64,Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DateTools.Resolution)
member.summary: Limit a date's resolution. For example, the date 1095767411000 (which represents 2004-09-21 13:50:11) will be changed to 1093989600000 (2004-09-01 00:00:00) when using Resolution.MONTH.
member.param: The desired resolution of the date to be returned
member.returns: the date with all values more precise than resolution set to 0 or 1, expressed as milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT

member.name: M:Raven.Abstractions.Linq.DynamicJsonObject.TryGetMember(System.Dynamic.GetMemberBinder,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that get member values. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as getting a value for a property.
member.param: Provides information about the object that called the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member on which the dynamic operation is performed. For example, for the Console.WriteLine(sampleObject.SampleProperty) statement, where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleProperty". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.
The result of the get operation. For example, if the method is called for a property, you can assign the property value to .
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a run-time exception is thrown.)
